title.narrative: Empower journalists and other media professionals, especially in developing countries, as key human rights defenders, so that they are better able to hold governments accountable against the State’s international human rights obligations and commitments

Empower journalists and other media professionals, especially in developing countries, as key human rights defenders, so that they are better able to hold governments accountable against the State’s international human rights obligations and commitments

comment.narrative: URG’s 2016 report, and articles on the Council published since then (e.g. in the Economist), suggest a relatively low level of interest in and knowledge of the Council amongst national journalists. That is especially the case for journalists from developing countries. As a consequence, relatively few articles are published about the Council and its work (both in absolute terms and compared to other parts of the UN such as the Security Council). Where articles are published, they often carry mistakes about the Council and its role, and/or focus very narrowly on the Council’s response to situations of gross and systematic human rights violations.

comment.narrative: Very low levels of media interest and media coverage of the Council in the target countries. Media interest in the Council, where it does exist (mainly in Western media), is generally focused only on the body’s response to situations of gross and systematic violations – the rest of the Council’s work is almost completely ignored.
